items.content_html:
Summary

This PR adds a compatibility and spec's for the SVG shape-subtract attribute. A follow up to my PR adding this item to the MDN docs.

First time contributor here, please feel free to let me know if there was something I could've done better.

Test results and supporting details

In my testing for compatibility I was unable to find a browser that supported this feature, even though it is on the standards track.

Testing as Not Supported in:

  • Chrome: 110.0.581.178
  • Firefox: 110.0.1
  • Opera: 95.0.4635.46
  • Edge: 110.0.1587.63

But there are some resources that indicate it could be a WIP:

  • Chromium Bug report asking for this feature support
  • Chromium Test Cases for this Feature
  • Firefox Test Cases for this Feature

Also if helpful, the specification.

Related issues

Supplies my companion PR mdn/content#25077 with it's compatibility table and specification link.
items.title: Add `shape-subtract` compatibility data

items.content_html:
FF111 added support for OPFS in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1811001. I added the main API in #18907 but it never occurred to me that the rest of the file system around this was not supported. So as per https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1811001#c11 this updates the interfaces in the File System Access API to indicate they are also supported.

  • FileSystemWritableFileStream
  • FileSystemDirectoryHandle
  • FileSystemFileHandle
  • FileSystemFileHandle
  • FileSystemSyncAccessHandle

Note, WritableStream is already marked as supported from FF100

@saschanaz Can you confirm this issue delivers full support for the API / that this is the right set of things to mark as supported in FF111?
items.title: Ff111 More OPFS related updaes

items.content_html:
Firefox does not support dynamic module imports in workers - see https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1540913 (and discussion in #19044 ).

This adds a worker support feature to import() and sets FF to false with a bug link.

The rest was copied from the parent and is untested. @evilpie Can you advise on a WPT test that I run to test dynamic import support for the other platforms (and are you aware of any others that do not have this support)?

This follows on from work in mdn/content#24402
items.title: FF does not support dynamic module import in workers

items.content_html:
There is a note in Worker:

Following the bug you start to see support for nested workers in 15.5 - https://webkit.org/blog/13338/release-notes-for-safari-technology-preview-155/ and in 16.4 it looks like there were some other fixes that are relevant: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/safari-release-notes/safari-16_4-release-notes
There might be more, but they are definitely supported in 15.5 and looks like it might be pretty much full support now.

Anyway, I have added this information as notes. Not sure if this is "correct enough". Should I make the original entry a partial implementation and have a separate "full support" entry at 15.5?

FYI @queengooborg

This fell out of work in mdn/content#24402

  • Once this goes in, remove that note above
items.title: Add compatibility note about Safari's support for nested workers

items.content_html:
Summary

Fixes/improves the support data for the CSS mask shorthand property for Firefox and Safari.

  • Firefox: marked the Firefox 2 entry as partial support; added an entry with the version which added support for CSS Masking Module Level 1.
  • Safari: added an entry for Safari 15.4, which shipped the unprefixed mask property.

Test results and supporting details

My rationale was that the support data should be a rough match for “does this browser support the CSS Masking Level 1: Positioned Masks feature?”

In the case of Firefox, relevant release notes are:

  • Firefox 2 (the version that is in the current data): no mentions of masks.
  • Firefox 10: mention of a change to the color space used for SVG masks.
  • Firefox 47: adds CSS Mask Image support in Nightly.
  • Firefox 53: ships CSS Masks by default.

I could not find a description of what the mask property did in Firefox 2+ and before Firefox 53. My memory tells me that it supported SVG masks (as mask: url(image.svg)) so I wrote that down in the notes. It's also far enough from the CSS Masking Module definition of mask to warrant a “partial implementation” flag.

The notes for Firefox 2+ had an extract from the Firefox 10 release notes about sRGB vs Linear RGB and Firefox aligning with the SVG 1.1 spec, which IMHO is a minute implementation detail that may not be worth mentioning.

For Safari, it shipped the unprefixed mask property in Safari 15.4 (release notes).

Retiring WebKit prefixes

In an ongoing effort to reduce dependency on prefixes, WebKit newly supports several CSS properties and values that were only previous available in an earlier form. The prefixed versions will still work, now aliased to the unprefixed versions. Safari 15.4 added support for:

  • appearance, including appearance: auto
  • mask, along with the long-hand forms mask-image, mask-size, mask-repeat-x, mask-repeat-y, mask-origin
  • backface-visibility
  • text-combine-upright
  • print-color-adjust
  • match-parent CSS value for the text-align property
items.title: Fix support data for the CSS mask shorthand property

items.content_html: This PR removes the irrelevant type member of the HTMLMenuElement API as per the corresponding data guidelines. The lack of current support has been confirmed by the mdn-bcd-collector project (v8.0.0), even if the current BCD suggests support.

items.content_html:
NodeList.forEach has no spec, which is a bit ugly in the docs. The reason is that forEach and @@iterator are implied because NodeList is and iterable.

There is literally nowhere to link to in NodeList in the spec https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#nodelist to point to iterable. We could link to NodeList itself but that would look like a typo.

So my proposal is that we link to the Web IDL spec for both of these: https://webidl.spec.whatwg.org/#idl-iterable - see the text:

n the ECMAScript language binding, an interface that is iterable will have entries, forEach, keys, values, and @@iterator properties on its interface prototype object.

OK? FYI @wbamberg @queengooborg @Josh-Cena

Fixes mdn/content#24653
items.title: NodeList - spec link for forEach and @@iterator

items.content_html:
FF111 support RTCInboundRtpStreamStats.trackIdentifier in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1804676

Unfortunately RTCInboundRtpStreamStats has no BCD entry. I know that we don't like having dictionary entries, but I don't want to untangle that mess now. So I'm starting by creating one.

Strategy has been to create a full BCD with entries for all values and spec links. I have then for FF111, Chrome 110 and Safari 16 gone through using this wpt example RTCPeerConnection-mandatory-getStats.https.html. Breaking on the point shown below and then iterating until I get a stat object of type inbound-rtp. This is the correct type to return this dictionary.

test(t => {
    for (const stat of stats.values()) {
      let dictName = dictionaryNames[stat.type];
>>      if (!dictName) continue;

BCD is cracking it because true is not valid version. However testing each of these would be a challenge. For a start, Safari only allows me to test back to 14.1 using this test.

@queengooborg - any suggestions on what values I can use, ideally without having to bisect such a large number of properties for each browser?

Other docs work for this can be tracked in mdn/content#24397

NOte, I do have info for FF

  • FF55 data https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1348657 : Implement framesEncoded, pliCount, nackCount and firCount in webrtc stats
  • FF56 https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1374465 framesDecoded
  • FF104 https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1780282 Implement some more inbound rtp stats.
    framesPerSecond, jitterBufferDelay, jitterBufferEmittedCount, totalSamplesReceived, concealedSamples, silentConcealedSamples
  • FF101: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1766473 Implement some inbound and outbound rtc stats needed for MS Teams : frameWidth, frameHeight, framesReceived
  • FF111 https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1728357 framesDropped
  • FF106 https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1790508 Add newly available RTP and RTCP stats: qpSum, totalDecodeTime, totalInterFrameDelay, totalSquaredInterFrameDelay, lastPacketReceivedTimestamp, headerBytesReceived, fecPacketsReceived, fecPacketsDiscarded, totalProcessingDelay, concealmentEvents, insertedSamplesForDeceleration, removedSamplesForAcceleration, audioLevel, totalAudioEnergy, totalSamplesDuration
  • FF68 https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1515716 Refactor WebRTC RTP stats types: remoteId, framesDecoded, bytesReceived, nackCount
  • FF63 https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1481851 getStats: kind is missing from RTPStreamStats - but note this is seen as inbound by recipient
  • FF tests - what is expected: https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/dom/media/webrtc/tests/mochitests/stats.js#8_
  • Chrome 79 bytesReceived: https://groups.google.com/g/discuss-webrtc/c/X8q5Ae9VKco/m/oEiGuteoBAAJ
  • Chrome 111 totalInterFrameDelay: https://groups.google.com/g/discuss-webrtc/c/qo2-96L5jEw
  • Chrome 111 playoutid. From link above, can then find it in changelist: https://webrtc.googlesource.com/src.git/+log/refs/branch-heads/5563?pli=1#
items.title: RTCInboundRtpStreamStats.trackIdentifier + the whole dictionary
